paragraph: We might say that the real transference taught in the Christian community is the condition absolutely necessary for the efficacy of the miracle of redemption; the first letter of John comes out frankly with this:“He that loveth his brother abideth in the light.”—_I John_ ii: 10.“If we love one another, God abideth in us.”—_I John_ iv: 12.The Deity continues to be efficacious in the Christian religion only upon the foundation of brotherly love. Consequently, here too the mystery of redemption is the unresisting real transference.[87] One may properly ask one’s self, for what then is the Deity useful, if his efficacy consists only in the _real transference_? To this also the evangelical message has a striking answer:“Men are all brothers in Christ.”“So Christ also, having been once offered to bear the sins of many,  shall appear a second time apart from sin to them that wait for him  unto salvation.”—_Heb._ ix: 28.
question: What does the first letter of John (1 John) suggest is essential for the efficacy of the miracle of redemption?
answer: The first letter of John suggests that brotherly love is essential for the efficacy of the miracle of redemption. Specifically, it states, "He that loveth his brother abideth in the light" and "If we love one another, God abideth in us."
